variants.input_context: Variants in PINK1, such as p.G363S and p.G363D, have been shown to cause loss-of-function and are associated with Parkinson's disease.
Variants in PINK1, such as p.G363S and p.G363D, have been shown to cause loss-of-function and are associated with Parkinson's disease.

experiments.readout: Quantitative analysis of PINK1 protein levels showed reduced expression in variants p.G363S and p.G363D compared to wild-type.
experiments.conclusion: Loss-of-function effects in PINK1 variants are associated with impaired mitophagy.
experiments.threshold: Protein levels below 50% of wild-type were classified as loss-of-function (based on literature).

experiments.readout: Reduced interaction between PINK1 variants (p.G363S and p.G363D) and PARKIN compared to wild-type PINK1.
experiments.conclusion: Mutations in PINK1 disrupt mitochondrial dynamics and lead to neurodegeneration.
experiments.threshold: Interaction below 30% of wild-type was classified as significant disruption (based on literature).
